addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable my very singular good Lord
e L. Burghley Lord highe Treasurer of England.

23 A
p
1592 M
r
Bodeleie to my L.
The
D. of Parmas
Message to
Comte Mawrice
./

page.lettertext:
fol.261r
May it please yo
r
good L. I have bin infor-
med very lately by a frind of good credit,
and countenance, and one
at doth assure
me of
e truth of his report, That w
t
in this
moneth there came a secret messenger to Count
Maurice, w
t
a letter of credence from the D.
of Parma. The partie was knowen to
e autor
of this advertisment, an
Utrecht
man borne
and very well q
a
lified. Assoone as he
came hither he addressed himself to
M
r
Sonsfilde
,
one
at hath governed
e Count in all his youth,
and is continually neere about him:
e self
same party, to whome
Mons
r
Bilandt
, before
his comming to
e Hage writte a letter of per-
suasion to move him to favor
e mater of
Pacification. By this gentlemans meanes
e
Count was informed of
e messengers c
o
ming,
and gave him leave to doe his message, but in
e presence of some others, w
ch
were
Mons
r
de
Fauma
, who is
e Governo
r
of
Hoesden,
M
r
Barnevelt
, and
e said M
r
Sonsfilde. After
that
e Messenger had exhibited his Credence,
he saluted
e Count in
e name of
e Duke, w
t
very honorable complements, declaring his de-
sire to advance his estate, and wishing ther-
upon
at he would hearken to a Treaty: whiche
in case he would admitte, and persuade the
C ontrey to
e like, suche conditions should be graun-
ted as he himself would require. For although
the
kinge of Spaine
should refuse to yelde
unto
them, he had meanes enough to force him, w
ch
he
should see him putte in practise.
The Count
would make no answear to this message of
e
partie, but dimissed him presently, and after
fol.261v
some time of his aboade in this place gave him
licence to be gone. He went from hens to Utrecht,
where assoone as he arrived, M
r
Barnevelt had
written to
e Officers of
e towne, to examine
him strictly about his comming to
at place. How-
beit w
t
in a day or two after, he writte againe to
discharge him. This is all
at
e partie
could tell me of this mater: w
ch
he assured me
was true. But for any other circumstance, whe-
ther there passed any more between
e Duke and
the Count, ether after or before, he was utterly igno-
rant: w
ch
I thought very fitte to advertise yo
r
L.
and so I take my humble leave.
From
e Hage. A
p
23 1592.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
